14. But Dürer’s Fabric, especially the last
one sees in his prints, with such
magnificently large flat areas, leaving
the rest in deep shadow, as his best
Mary figures show, is splendid and instructive.
It would be a great misdeed, and an ignoble thing,
to accuse such a Man of “confusion.”
The nature of Art will never tolerate it.
left-middleExample: cloth with flat areas by Albrecht Dürer.

15. The pride of the Batavians and of the Germans,
Lucas, and Albrecht, on whom the Chorus of Muses
has showered all its gifts, have granted the Italians
great profit and benefit with their prints,
and thus, their draperies. Yes, perhaps
even more than one could think,
because, with skill and intelligence,
they knew how to vary a little.

16. In Lucas’s cloth one finds many fine ruffles.
In the Magdalen, Mordecai, and The Temptation of Christ
one sees him execute the movement
of small folds with his skilled burin.
Who could pour out this flow with greater delicacy?
Now Youths, like Bees, you would do well
to suck from these Roses the dripping nectar
and sweet honey, unusually useful.

17. Without faltering, make a flowing Cloth,
rich and unbound, particularly for Women;
it would not be easy to reproach you.
Rather than making it too short, you should let it trail.
And like the branches adorning the trees,
make the edges and hems ripple naturally
when hanging or spreading,
but avoid making crooked corners.

18. Now concerning silks and various sheens,
the Venetians are in general highly praised;
they will serve as a good Example.
They know how to work with colors,
and arrange them so that the highlights
seem to protrude: but one must always
add to shining silks such highlights
as the Adjacent colors can best support
left-middleExample: Venetian Painters’ beautiful silks and sheens, or changeable silks.
